questions.question: A sprinter finishes a race by decelerating uniformly from $11.5\text{ m/s}$ to a walking speed of $1.5\text{ m/s}$ over a distance of $18\text{ m}$. Calculate the sprinter's constant acceleration.
questions.explanation: Using $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2ad$: $(1.5)^2 = (11.5)^2 + 2a(18) \rightarrow 2.25 = 132.25 + 36a \rightarrow 36a = -130 \rightarrow a = -130/36 \approx -3.61 \approx -3.6\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A remote-controlled car travels at a constant speed of $4.0\text{ m/s}$ and then accelerates uniformly at $1.4\text{ m/s}^2$ for $5.0\text{ s}$. Determine the total displacement of the car during this $5.0\text{ s}$ acceleration period.
An arrow is shot vertically upward from ground level and reaches a maximum height of $38\text{ m}$. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the initial launch speed of the arrow.
questions.explanation: Using $v_f^2 = v_i^2 - 2gh$ with $v_f = 0$: $0 = v_i^2 - 2(9.8)(38) \rightarrow v_i = \sqrt{2 \times 9.8 \times 38} = \sqrt{744.8} \approx 27.29 \approx 27\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A rock is thrown vertically downward from a $45\text{ m}$ high bridge with an initial speed of $6.0\text{ m/s}$. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the velocity of the rock as it hits the water below.
A tennis ball is served horizontally from a height of $2.4\text{ m}$ and lands $19\text{ m}$ away from the baseline. Neglecting air resistance, calculate the initial horizontal velocity of the ball.
questions.explanation: Time of fall: $t = \sqrt{2h/g} = \sqrt{4.8/9.8} = \sqrt{0.4898} = 0.699\text{ s}$. Horizontal velocity: $v_x = d/t = 19/0.699 \approx 27.18 \approx 27\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A projectile is launched at an angle of $35^{\circ}$ above the horizontal with a speed of $42\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the horizontal distance it has traveled when it reaches its peak altitude.
questions.explanation: Time to peak: $t_{peak} = \frac{v_i \sin\theta}{g} = \frac{42 \times \sin35^{\circ}}{9.8} = \frac{42 \times 0.5736}{9.8} = \frac{24.09}{9.8} = 2.46\text{ s}$. Horizontal component: $v_x = v_i \cos\theta = 42 \times 0.8192 = 34.41\text{ m/s}$. Horizontal distance: $x = v_x t_{peak} = 34.41 \times 2.46 \approx 84.65 \approx 85\text{ m}$.

questions.question: Determine the total time of flight for a golf ball hit from level ground with an initial speed of $32\text{ m/s}$ at an angle of $55^{\circ}$ above the horizontal.
questions.explanation: $T = \frac{2v_i \sin\theta}{g} = \frac{2 \times 32 \times \sin55^{\circ}}{9.8} = \frac{64 \times 0.8192}{9.8} = \frac{52.43}{9.8} \approx 5.35 \approx 5.4\text{ s}$.

questions.question: A swimmer can swim at a speed of $1.2\text{ m/s}$ in still water. They aim directly across a river that is $60\text{ m}$ wide. If the river current flows at $0.90\text{ m/s}$, calculate the magnitude of their resultant velocity relative to the bank.
questions.explanation: The two velocity components are perpendicular, so the resultant speed is $v = \sqrt{1.2^2 + 0.9^2} = \sqrt{1.44 + 0.81} = \sqrt{2.25} = 1.5\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: Car A moves North at $85\text{ km/h}$ and Car B moves East at $60\text{ km/h}$. Calculate the velocity of Car B relative to Car A, giving both magnitude and direction.
questions.explanation: Magnitude: $|\vec{v}_{B/A}| = \sqrt{85^2 + 60^2} = \sqrt{7225 + 3600} = \sqrt{10825} \approx 104.0 \approx 1.0 \times 10^2\text{ km/h}$. Direction: $\theta = \tan^{-1}(85/60) = \tan^{-1}(1.4167) \approx 54.8^{\circ} \approx 55^{\circ}$ south of east.

questions.question: A $14\text{ kg}$ block is pulled across a horizontal surface by a horizontal force of $75\text{ N}$. If the acceleration of the block is $2.2\text{ m/s}^2$, calculate the coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the surface.
questions.explanation: Net force: $F_{net} = ma = 14 \times 2.2 = 30.8\text{ N}$. Friction force: $f_k = F_{app} - F_{net} = 75 - 30.8 = 44.2\text{ N}$. Coefficient: $\mu_k = f_k/(mg) = 44.2/(14 \times 9.8) = 44.2/137.2 \approx 0.322 \approx 0.32$.

questions.question: A $1200\text{ kg}$ car's brakes provide a maximum braking force of $6500\text{ N}$. Assuming constant braking force, calculate the distance needed to stop the car from an initial speed of $24\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: Deceleration: $a = F/m = 6500/1200 = 5.417\text{ m/s}^2$. Stopping distance: $d = v^2/(2a) = (24)^2/(2 \times 5.417) = 576/10.834 \approx 53.16 \approx 53\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A $0.50\text{ kg}$ object is pushed with a force of $15\text{ N}$ directed at an angle of $25^{\circ}$ below the horizontal. If the surface is frictionless, calculate the normal force acting on the object.
questions.explanation: Vertical component of the applied force: $F_y = 15\sin25^{\circ} = 15 \times 0.4226 = 6.34\text{ N}$ (downward). Normal force: $N = mg + F_y = 0.50 \times 9.8 + 6.34 = 4.9 + 6.34 = 11.24 \approx 11\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $9.0\text{ kg}$ block is placed on an incline that makes an angle of $22^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. Calculate the component of the gravitational force acting parallel to the surface of the incline.
questions.explanation: $F_\parallel = mg\sin\theta = 9.0 \times 9.8 \times \sin22^{\circ} = 88.2 \times 0.3746 \approx 33.04 \approx 33\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A crate slides down a $30^{\circ}$ ramp with an acceleration of $1.5\text{ m/s}^2$. Calculate the coefficient of kinetic friction between the crate and the ramp.
questions.explanation: For an object sliding down an incline, $a = g\sin\theta - \mu_k g\cos\theta$. Thus $1.5 = 9.8\sin30^{\circ} - \mu_k(9.8)\cos30^{\circ} = 4.9 - 8.487\mu_k$. Solving: $8.487\mu_k = 3.4 \rightarrow \mu_k = 3.4/8.487 \approx 0.401 \approx 0.40$.

questions.question: Two masses, $12\text{ kg}$ and $8.0\text{ kg}$, are connected by a light string over a frictionless, massless pulley in an Atwood machine. Starting from rest, calculate the distance the masses move in the first $1.2\text{ s}$.
questions.explanation: Acceleration: $a = g\frac{m_2 - m_1}{m_1 + m_2} = 9.8 \times \frac{12 - 8}{20} = 9.8 \times \frac{4}{20} = 9.8 \times 0.2 = 1.96\text{ m/s}^2$. Distance: $d = \frac{1}{2}at^2 = 0.5 \times 1.96 \times (1.2)^2 = 0.98 \times 1.44 = 1.411 \approx 1.4\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A $15\text{ kg}$ mass on a horizontal frictionless table is connected by a light string over a frictionless pulley to a $4.5\text{ kg}$ hanging mass. Calculate the tension in the string during motion.
questions.explanation: Acceleration: $a = \frac{m_2g}{m_1 + m_2} = \frac{4.5 \times 9.8}{19.5} = \frac{44.1}{19.5} = 2.262\text{ m/s}^2$. Tension: $T = m_1a = 15 \times 2.262 = 33.93 \approx 34\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $1.2\text{ kg}$ sign is suspended by two wires that make an angle of $140^{\circ}$ with each other. Calculate the tension in each wire.
questions.explanation: If the wires make $140^{\circ}$ with each other, each wire makes $70^{\circ}$ with the vertical. Vertical equilibrium: $2T\cos70^{\circ} = mg = 1.2 \times 9.8 = 11.76\text{ N}$. Since $\cos70^{\circ} = 0.3420$, $2T(0.3420) = 0.684T = 11.76 \rightarrow T = 11.76/0.684 \approx 17.19 \approx 17\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $72\text{ kg}$ person stands on a scale in an elevator that is accelerating upward at $2.5\text{ m/s}^2$. Calculate the reading on the scale in Newtons.
questions.explanation: When accelerating upward, the scale reading (normal force) is $F_N = m(g + a) = 72(9.8 + 2.5) = 72 \times 12.3 = 885.6 \approx 890\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A centrifuge rotates at $3500\text{ rpm}$ (revolutions per minute). Calculate the centripetal acceleration of a sample located $8.0\text{ cm}$ from the axis of rotation.
questions.explanation: Angular velocity: $\omega = 3500 \times \frac{2\pi}{60} = 3500 \times 0.10472 = 366.5\text{ rad/s}$. Centripetal acceleration: $a_c = r\omega^2 = 0.08 \times (366.5)^2 = 0.08 \times 134,322 \approx 10,746 \approx 1.1 \times 10^4\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A ball is swung in a circle of radius $0.65\text{ m}$ with a constant tangential speed of $4.5\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the period of the motion.
questions.explanation: Period: $T = \frac{2\pi r}{v} = \frac{2\pi \times 0.65}{4.5} = \frac{4.084}{4.5} \approx 0.907 \approx 0.91\text{ s}$.

questions.question: A $0.35\text{ kg}$ mass is whirled in a vertical circle of radius $1.1\text{ m}$. If the speed at the top of the circle is $4.2\text{ m/s}$, calculate the tension in the string at that point.
questions.explanation: At the top, $T + mg = \frac{mv^2}{r} \rightarrow T = m\left(\frac{v^2}{r} - g\right) = 0.35\left(\frac{4.2^2}{1.1} - 9.8\right) = 0.35\left(\frac{17.64}{1.1} - 9.8\right) = 0.35(16.04 - 9.8) = 0.35 \times 6.24 \approx 2.18 \approx 2.2\text{ N}$.

questions.question: Calculate the minimum speed a bucket of water must have at the top of a vertical circle with a radius of $0.85\text{ m}$ so that the water does not fall out.
questions.explanation: The minimum speed occurs when the tension is zero and gravity alone provides the centripetal force: $mg = \frac{mv^2}{r} \rightarrow v = \sqrt{gr} = \sqrt{9.8 \times 0.85} = \sqrt{8.33} \approx 2.89 \approx 2.9\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A car of mass $1100\text{ kg}$ rounds a flat, unbanked curve with a radius of $48\text{ m}$. If the coefficient of static friction between the tires and the road is $0.65$, calculate the maximum constant speed the car can maintain without skidding.
questions.explanation: The friction force provides the centripetal force: $\mu_s mg = \frac{mv^2}{r} \rightarrow v = \sqrt{\mu_s g r} = \sqrt{0.65 \times 9.8 \times 48} = \sqrt{305.76} \approx 17.49 \approx 17\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A $0.40\text{ kg}$ ball is swung in a horizontal circle of radius $0.75\text{ m}$ with a frequency of $2.5\text{ Hz}$. Calculate the centripetal force acting on the ball.
questions.explanation: Tangential speed: $v = 2\pi r f = 2\pi \times 0.75 \times 2.5 = 4.712 \times 2.5 = 11.78\text{ m/s}$. Centripetal force: $F_c = \frac{mv^2}{r} = \frac{0.40 \times (11.78)^2}{0.75} = \frac{0.40 \times 138.8}{0.75} = \frac{55.52}{0.75} \approx 74.03 \approx 74\text{ N}$.

questions.question: Calculate the gravitational force between a $75\text{ kg}$ person and a $2200\text{ kg}$ lead sphere when their centers are $2.5\text{ m}$ apart. Use $G = 6.67 \times 10^{-11}\text{ N·m}^2/\text{kg}^2$.
A planet has $3.0$ times the mass of Earth but only $0.80$ times the radius of Earth. Calculate the acceleration due to gravity on its surface. (Take $g_{Earth} = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.)
questions.explanation: $g_p = G\frac{3M_E}{(0.8R_E)^2} = \frac{3}{0.64} \times G\frac{M_E}{R_E^2} = 4.6875 \times 9.8 \approx 45.94 \approx 46\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A $18\text{ kg}$ box is pushed a distance of $11\text{ m}$ across a floor at a constant speed. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the box and the floor is $0.22$, calculate the work done by the applied force.
questions.explanation: At constant speed, the applied force equals the friction force: $F_{app} = f_k = \mu_k mg = 0.22 \times 18 \times 9.8 = 0.22 \times 176.4 = 38.81\text{ N}$. Work done: $W = F_{app} d = 38.81 \times 11 \approx 426.9 \approx 430\text{ J}$.

questions.question: Calculate the work required to accelerate a hockey puck of mass $0.16\text{ kg}$ from a speed of $5.0\text{ m/s}$ to a speed of $28\text{ m/s}$.

A $1400\text{ kg}$ car is traveling at $22\text{ m/s}$. If the engine provides a constant forward force of $4500\text{ N}$ over a distance of $60\text{ m}$, calculate the final speed of the car. Ignore friction and air resistance.
questions.explanation: Work done by the engine: $W = Fd = 4500 \times 60 = 270,000\text{ J}$. Initial kinetic energy: $KE_i = \frac{1}{2}mv_i^2 = 0.5 \times 1400 \times 484 = 700 \times 484 = 338,800\text{ J}$. Final kinetic energy: $KE_f = KE_i + W = 338,800 + 270,000 = 608,800\text{ J}$. Final speed: $v_f = \sqrt{2KE_f/m} = \sqrt{1,217,600/1400} = \sqrt{869.7} \approx 29.49 \approx 30\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A $0.42\text{ kg}$ ball is dropped from a height of $16\text{ m}$. It rebounds to a height of $11\text{ m}$. Calculate the amount of energy lost during the impact with the ground.
questions.explanation: Energy lost equals the change in potential energy: $E_{lost} = mg(h_i - h_f) = 0.42 \times 9.8 \times (16 - 11) = 0.42 \times 9.8 \times 5 = 0.42 \times 49 = 20.58 \approx 21\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A $2.5\text{ kg}$ block is compressed against a horizontal spring with spring constant $k = 750\text{ N/m}$ by a distance of $0.14\text{ m}$. It is then released. Assuming no friction, calculate the speed of the block after it has traveled $0.08\text{ m}$ from the release point.
questions.explanation: Initial energy: $E_i = \frac{1}{2}kx_i^2 = 0.5 \times 750 \times (0.14)^2 = 375 \times 0.0196 = 7.35\text{ J}$. At a distance of $0.08\text{ m}$ from release, the spring compression is $x_f = 0.14 - 0.08 = 0.06\text{ m}$. Energy at this point: $E_f = \frac{1}{2}kx_f^2 + \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5 \times 750 \times (0.06)^2 + 0.5 \times 2.5 \times v^2 = 375 \times 0.0036 + 1.25v^2 = 1.35 + 1.25v^2$. Conservation of energy: $7.35 = 1.35 + 1.25v^2 \rightarrow 1.25v^2 = 6.0 \rightarrow v^2 = 4.8 \rightarrow v = \sqrt{4.8} \approx 2.19 \approx 2.2\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A $1.1\text{ kW}$ electric motor is used to lift a $180\text{ kg}$ load vertically at a constant speed. Calculate the time it takes to lift the load a distance of $14\text{ m}$.
questions.explanation: Work required: $W = mgh = 180 \times 9.8 \times 14 = 180 \times 137.2 = 24,696\text{ J}$. Time: $t = W/P = 24,696/1100 \approx 22.45 \approx 22\text{ s}$.

questions.question: Calculate the power output of a cyclist who exerts a constant force of $35\text{ N}$ to maintain a constant speed of $12\text{ m/s}$ on a level road.
questions.explanation: $P = Fv = 35 \times 12 = 420\text{ W}$.

questions.question: A spring is stretched by $0.060\text{ m}$ when a $15\text{ N}$ force is applied. Calculate the elastic potential energy stored in the spring.
questions.explanation: Spring constant: $k = F/x = 15/0.06 = 250\text{ N/m}$. Elastic potential energy: $EPE = \frac{1}{2}kx^2 = 0.5 \times 250 \times (0.06)^2 = 125 \times 0.0036 = 0.45\text{ J}$.

questions.question: Calculate the work required to compress a spring with spring constant $k = 1200\text{ N/m}$ from an initial compression of $0.020\text{ m}$ to a final compression of $0.10\text{ m}$.
A $0.55\text{ kg}$ ball moving North at $4.0\text{ m/s}$ collides head-on with a stationary $0.85\text{ kg}$ ball. If they stick together after the collision, calculate their final velocity.
questions.explanation: Conservation of momentum: $m_1v_1 = (m_1 + m_2)v_f \rightarrow 0.55 \times 4.0 = (0.55 + 0.85)v_f \rightarrow 2.2 = 1.4v_f \rightarrow v_f = 2.2/1.4 \approx 1.571 \approx 1.6\text{ m/s North}$.

questions.question: In a perfectly elastic head-on collision, a $2.0\text{ kg}$ mass moving at $6.0\text{ m/s}$ hits a stationary $1.0\text{ kg}$ mass. Calculate the final velocity of the $2.0\text{ kg}$ mass.
questions.explanation: For an elastic collision, $v_{1f} = \frac{m_1 - m_2}{m_1 + m_2}v_1 = \frac{2.0 - 1.0}{3.0} \times 6.0 = \frac{1}{3} \times 6 = 2.0\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A $2.4\text{ kg}$ firework initially at rest explodes into two pieces. One piece has a mass of $0.80\text{ kg}$ and moves East at $32\text{ m/s}$. Calculate the velocity of the second piece.
questions.explanation: Mass of second piece: $m_2 = 2.4 - 0.8 = 1.6\text{ kg}$. Conservation of momentum: $0 = m_1v_1 + m_2v_2 \rightarrow 0 = 0.8(32) + 1.6v_2 \rightarrow 1.6v_2 = -25.6 \rightarrow v_2 = -25.6/1.6 = -16\text{ m/s}$, which means $16\text{ m/s}$ West.

questions.question: Three resistors with resistances $15\Omega$, $35\Omega$, and $50\Omega$ are connected in series to a $12\text{ V}$ battery. Calculate the current in the circuit.
questions.explanation: Total resistance: $R_{total} = 15 + 35 + 50 = 100\Omega$. Current: $I = V/R_{total} = 12/100 = 0.12\text{ A}$.

questions.question: A $9.0\text{ V}$ source is connected to two resistors in series. If $R_1 = 120\Omega$ and the voltage across it is $3.0\text{ V}$, calculate the resistance of $R_2$.
questions.explanation: Current: $I = V_1/R_1 = 3.0/120 = 0.025\text{ A}$. Voltage across $R_2$: $V_2 = 9.0 - 3.0 = 6.0\text{ V}$. Resistance: $R_2 = V_2/I = 6.0/0.025 = 240\Omega$.

questions.question: Calculate the equivalent resistance of a $45\Omega$ resistor and a $90\Omega$ resistor connected in parallel.
Two resistors are connected in parallel across a $24\text{ V}$ source. If the total current drawn from the source is $1.6\text{ A}$ and $R_1 = 30\Omega$, find the value of $R_2$.
questions.explanation: Equivalent resistance: $R_{total} = V/I = 24/1.6 = 15\Omega$. For two resistors in parallel: $\frac{1}{15} = \frac{1}{30} + \frac{1}{R_2} \rightarrow \frac{1}{R_2} = \frac{1}{15} - \frac{1}{30} = \frac{2}{30} - \frac{1}{30} = \frac{1}{30} \rightarrow R_2 = 30\Omega$.

questions.question: A $25\Omega$ resistor is connected in series with a parallel combination of two $40\Omega$ resistors. Calculate the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.
questions.explanation: The two $40\Omega$ resistors in parallel give $R_p = 40/2 = 20\Omega$. Total resistance: $R_{total} = 25 + 20 = 45\Omega$.

questions.question: A $12\text{ V}$ source is connected to a circuit consisting of a $10\Omega$ resistor in series with a parallel combination of two $20\Omega$ resistors. Calculate the current through the $10\Omega$ resistor.
questions.explanation: The two $20\Omega$ resistors in parallel give $R_p = 20/2 = 10\Omega$. Total resistance: $R_{total} = 10 + 10 = 20\Omega$. Total current (which flows through the series $10\Omega$ resistor) is $I = V/R_{total} = 12/20 = 0.60\text{ A}$.

questions.question: A wave has a frequency of $440\text{ Hz}$ and a wavelength of $0.78\text{ m}$. Calculate the speed of the wave.
questions.explanation: $v = f\lambda = 440 \times 0.78 = 343.2 \approx 340\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A string is $3.2\text{ m}$ long and has a total mass of $28\text{ g}$. If it is under a tension of $95\text{ N}$, calculate the speed of a wave on this string.
questions.explanation: Linear mass density: $\mu = m/L = 0.028/3.2 = 0.00875\text{ kg/m}$. Wave speed: $v = \sqrt{T/\mu} = \sqrt{95/0.00875} = \sqrt{10857} \approx 104.2 \approx 1.0 \times 10^2\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: An ambulance siren emits a sound with frequency $800\text{ Hz}$. A stationary observer hears the siren at $860\text{ Hz}$. Calculate the speed of the ambulance. The speed of sound is $340\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: The observed frequency is higher than the emitted frequency, so the ambulance is approaching. Using $f' = f\frac{v}{v - v_s}$: $860 = 800 \times \frac{340}{340 - v_s} \rightarrow \frac{860}{800} = \frac{340}{340 - v_s} \rightarrow 1.075 = \frac{340}{340 - v_s} \rightarrow 340 - v_s = 340/1.075 = 316.28 \rightarrow v_s = 340 - 316.28 = 23.72 \approx 24\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: Two speakers emit sound in phase. Constructive interference occurs at a point where the path difference from the speakers is $1.5\text{ m}$. Calculate the lowest possible frequency of the sound. The speed of sound is $344\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: For constructive interference with in-phase sources, the condition is $\Delta x = n\lambda$. For the lowest frequency, take $n = 1$, giving $1.5 = \lambda \rightarrow \lambda = 1.5\text{ m}$. Then $f = v/\lambda = 344/1.5 \approx 229.3 \approx 230\text{ Hz}$.

questions.question: Calculate the fundamental frequency of an organ pipe that is $0.92\text{ m}$ long and open at both ends. The speed of sound is $340\text{ m/s}$.
questions.explanation: For an open pipe, the fundamental frequency is $f_1 = \frac{v}{2L} = \frac{340}{2 \times 0.92} = \frac{340}{1.84} \approx 184.8 \approx 180\text{ Hz}$ (closest to 180).

questions.question: Two tuning forks are struck simultaneously and produce $5$ beats per second. If one tuning fork has a frequency of $256\text{ Hz}$, what are the two possible frequencies of the other fork?
questions.explanation: Beat frequency: $f_{beat} = |f_2 - 256| = 5$. Therefore $f_2 = 256 - 5 = 251\text{ Hz}$ or $f_2 = 256 + 5 = 261\text{ Hz}$.
